abstract.p: Larry Bluth letter on Ben Ratliff's May 28 article blames universities music programs for loss of vitality in jazz solos (S)

block.p: Regarding Mr. Ratliff's astute observations about the loss of vitality in jazz solos: one might look at the way improvisation is being taught as a possible reason for this sad state of affairs. In universities, improvisation is being taught as instant composing rather than the intuitive response by the musician to the moment at hand. The loss of energy and immediacy that is insured by encouraging the student to ''hear it before you play it'' to my mind accounts for why so much soloing has become bland and uninteresting. I fear a different sensibility is robbing the music of its distinction. Jazz is not classical music.
